item.description:
A river runs through it

Showing the height field: Each triangular face is shaded with a diffuse lighting model based on dot products of the face normal & the direction of illumination (where is the sun? exercise for viewer)

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/FxhycogByH

The Cordillera

When we don't do a lot of pruning of side branches... https://t.co/dNVrEvgD4i

We can use a more boring height field. Previous ones use ridged fractal noise; here we use a single staight ridge line. Not so naturalistic, but interesting in its own way. https://t.co/ZNj9R10efJ

Rivers made by joining points in a hex grid, computing splines off joined channels for smoothing, w/ some pruning. To avoid straight lines, the actual point locations in the grid are jostled a bit. But... we can jostle them more, applying point-to-point function

A little warped https://t.co/HPBCxjBvsj

Lava cracks in the asteroid as it crashes into the atmosphere https://t.co/j62E1fIlW4

Mess with things enough, and it looks like alien cave art https://t.co/iBirIRsw4O

Excel to Excel using XML, really? (LB) Geert Bormans #balisage2022

Really wanted a bit more [shock!] validation/correction; early feedback on quality of data, as report

#balisage2022

item.description:
Multiple String Comparison in XSLT Joel Kalvesmaki #balisage2022

JK: Multiple string difference (N-way difference, octopus difference)

Differences should be weighed, not counted #balisage2022

JK: State of the field: many different diff utilities, mostly between 2 or 3, some with more #balisage2022

JK: Challenges: customization, visualization, quality #balisage2022

JK: tan:collate runs in log time by cumulative string, subquadratic in number of versions, pre- and post-processing,... #balisage2022

JK: tan:collate depends on tan:diff Algorithm based on notion of shared sample strings #balisage2022

JK: Logarithmic time, tokenization and other preprocessing not required #balisage2022

JK: tan:collate() iteratively uses tan:diff(), fast, except when there are lots and lots of versions

Realized approach was somewhat naive #balisage2022

JK: My approach evolved around concept of super-skeleton: look for long samples that appear in every version and use those as anchors, if can't find one, revert to older approach

#balisage2022

JK: So needed to update tan:diff() to handle N-way New implementation of tan:collate() now available (just recently) #balisage2022

JK: Test suite in paper based on gradual corruption of text; can measure quality, commonality, superskeleton metric

#balisage2022

JK: Comparing perf/quality of the three modes (naive no sort, CC/sort, superskeleton) wrt size of text, amount of corruption

Summary: looks good! #balisage2022

JK: Using tan:collate() Dev: import TAN library General: Use TAN Diff+ application #balisage2022

JK: (Demo) #balisage2022

item.description:
The Impossible Task of Comparing CALS Tables Robin La Fontaine, John Francis #balisage2022

RLF: Basic CALS table easy enough, but things can get more complex: horizontal spans: colspecs, namest/nameend as name refs to indicate spans vertical spans: morerows=n #balisage2022

RLF: Our approach for many years: use the native XML directly #balisage2022

RLF: Example of swapping columns: every cell in those columns shows a diff which is... not optimal #balisage2022

RLF: How to approach impossible problem? Step 1: Ignore something to make it a simpler problem Step 2: Solve simpler problem Step 3: Add back what was ignored to get improved result #balisage2022

RLF:

  1. Regularize to make rectangular grid
  2. Align columns based on content
  3. Key cells in each row based on column alignment
  4. Compare table rows using column alignment
  5. Restore spans based on B priority #balisage2022

RLF: (Shows some examples) #balisage2022

RLF: Difficulties Blank columns just to help with the rendering #balisage2022

RLF: Based on what users want, leads to need to user controls but that leads to complexity in implementation, testing, etc. Make sure defaults are good! Controls: column ordering, keying columns; use PIs for that #balisage2022

RLF: What makes a 'good' standard? Try to make sure only one way to represent something Avoid shorthands #balisage2022

RLF: Conclusions Native XML comparison works well most of the time, but is easily tripped up Content-based approach seems to be significant improvement Standards folks: avoid shorthands and multiple ways to represent same concept

item.description:
Biblical Linguistics in the GitHub Jungle (LB) Jonathan Robie #balisage2022

JR: Goal is to support Bible translations, data for high impact knowledge workers #balisage2022

JR: Knowledge is abundant: ability to use it is scarce #balisage2022

JR: Have a lot of data sets, and have partner data sets Morphology, syntax trees, word senses, glosses, transliterations, etc. Some of the "partners" are "something that was put up on github" and we want to use their data #balisage2022

JR: Data integration in practice Example: Hebrew syntax tree + morphology #balisage2022

JR: Some specific issues: extraneous LTR marker, use of pre-Unicode coding for Hebrew characters, ... #balisage2022

JR: "I'm going to teach you all linguistics and Biblical Hebrew and then get back to the example"

#balisage2022

JR: Example shows one dataset splits up one of the "words" and the other keeps it together

Need to establish common identifiers and units #balisage2022

JR: Spit out cases where text differs, then need to figure out why Different readings, different analysis of word boundaries, different spelling corrections, errors #balisage2022

JR: Trying to give you a flavour of this The integration took some time, and was quite tricky #balisage2022

item.description:
Project Mirabel: XQuery-Based Documentation Reporting and Exploration System Eliot Kimber #balisage2022

EK: Lot of content, lot of churn Authored in DITA XML, 200 writers around the globe OxygenXML desktop, GitHub enterprise storage, CI job to build #balisage2022

EK: "A lot of content, not a lot of management" #balisage2022

EK: Project Mirabel Goal: R/O access to information about content Metrics, dashboards, trends, content details, reports

Provide data to make data-driven decisions #balisage2022

EK: "Bundle" = top-level organizer for published content 40K topics => 30~ bundles =~ a product Bundle map => submap => topic #balisage2022

EK: "Excel for Validation Errors" Manual: validate w/ Oxygen, save as HTML, paste into Excel As once in a while, OK. As daily report... let's automate #balisage2022

EK: VP wanted dashboard, validation report Mad coding and getting up to speed on BaseX new features and XQuery 3 ensued #balisage2022

EK: Shout-out to "XQuery for Humanists" #balisage2022

EK: Create where-used and doc-to-bundle "easy" #balisage2022

EK: Bad data breaks good algorithm

Algorithm worked great on test case, but ran slowly over real data

Solution: process in ascending ref count order to avoid processing giant map

#balisage2022

EK: But I'm not going to stop there, because I am a menace

Want a content explorer

#balisage2022

EK: Challenges

  1. Managing concurrency in BaseX
  2. Optimizing queries
  3. Unix admin
  4. Serializing sequences updating operations
  5. DITA class-based processing (for perf dropped DTDs, which is where classes were...)
  6. Lack of browser UI dev skills #balisage2022

EK: XQuery as a language is actually accessible to Python and JavaScript programmers [MH has flashbacks to 5 years of internal arguments at Previous Employer] #balisage2022

item.description:
XSLT Extensions for JSON Processing Michael Kay #balisage2022

MK: Talk = Mix of ideas wrt JSON in XSLT; some cooked, some more half-baked #balisage2022

MK: What's in XSLT 3.0? Some JSON-specific things (parse/serialize/convert functions), some applicable to data model behind JSON (maps and arrays, various functions, esp. maps) #balisage2020

#balisage2022 Mary timetravels again

MK: Prague paper 2016 looked at JSON transformation and best way was JSON => XML => JSON Which is... disappointing Can we do better? Transform natively? #balisage2022

MK: Consider two use cases

  1. Leave everything except change one thing
  2. Hierarchical inversion #balisage2022

MK: Issues No array constructor Map construction not aligned with map deconstruction No ancestor access in JSON tree Poor support types/patterns matching maps/arrays (JSON maps don't have names) No suitable built-in template rules #balisage2022

MK: (Shows solutions to two use cases, using various proposed mechanisms, to be looked at in a bit) #balisage2022

MK: Record types New way of describing maps, both ItemType and Pattern List keys in map, can put * at end to make extensible, can make keys optional, can provide types, keys have to be strings but don't have to be NCNames, can define as recursive w/ 'as ..' #balisage2022

MK: Constructing/deconstructing maps and arrays Existing languages is sequence-focused, so want ways of decomposing array/map into sequence of pieces, and then reassemble map pieces are entries (key-value pairs) array pieces are parcels= item wraps sequence #balisage2022

MK: via() function to give access to apply-templates stack (replacement for ancestor) #balisage2022

MG: Developed to "reading ease" based on average words per sentence, average syllables per word #balisage2022

MG: For syntax elements, seems less is better #balisage2022

MG: characters in data names + value divided by total characters (minus whitespace and comments) #balisage2022

MG: Tricky areas comments, white space #balisage2022

MG: Issues/pain points Comments: ignore because JSON has no comments, so made it not comparable Commented-out code wrt readability? #balisage2022
